title: 'Historic' storm unleashes feet of snow, causes travel issues in parts of northern Rockies
text:
The northern Rockies are in the path of a potentially historic storm that is set to dump more than four feet of snow and bring wind gusts up to 60 mph.

The National Weather Service's prediction center said this could be a "significant and possibly historic" early-season snowstorm across portions of the northern Rockies. Forecasters warned the combination of heavy, wet snow, strong winds and bitter cold expected could set new records across the northwestern United States and southern Canada this early in the season.

"The snow that began to ramp up in the higher elevations of the Northwest on Saturday morning will only worsen and spread to lower elevations into Saturday night," AccuWeather Meteorologist Renee Duff said.

By Saturday afternoon local time, snowfall in Browning, Montana, nearly reached 2 feet, measuring 23 inches of total snowfall at 4:10 p.m. MDT.

Ahead of the storm, Glacier National Park in Montana announced road closures. While St. Mary Campground remains open, "camping not advised" signs have been put in place.

"The snow can pile up at quick pace, with more than an inch per hour possible," Duff said. By early afternoon local time, 13 inches of snow had been reported near Choteau, Montana. The report also mentioned that ice has started to cover highways that were previously plowed.

Due to severe winds, officials in Choteau, Montana, reported numerous downed power lines and trees on Saturday around noon, which created dangerous conditions.

"Strong winds accompanying the snow threaten to topple trees and power lines, as well as cause near-zero visibility and extensive blowing and drifting," Duff said.

Tree branches were starting to be weighed down by snow on Saturday morning in Montana.

"People are urged to not travel during the storm as there will be a heightened risk of becoming stranded in sub-freezing temperatures. If you must travel, make sure you have a fully charged cellphone, blankets and an emergency kit in your vehicle," Duff said. "Road closures are possible due to the poor driving conditions and debris blocking the roadway."

The live updates for this storm have been discontinued as of 7 p.m. MDT.

5:30 p.m. MDT Saturday

Browning, Montana, was closing in on 2 feet of snowfall at 4:10 p.m. MDT. Reduced visibility continues to be a hazard along roads near the city according to the Montana Department of Transportation, and snow continues to obscure RWIS images.

2:30 p.m. MDT Saturday

A total of 15 inches of snow was reported near Kiowa, Montana. Another report found that East Glacier Park, Montana, had also received 21 inches of snow.

Highways across northwestern Montana are experiencing reduced visibility due to blowing and drifting snow, according to the Montana Department of Transportation. The RWIS cameras that show more than just the white blur of snow show wintry scenes, the roads the only color peaking out from under the white snow.

Visibility has been greatly reduced along highways in northwestern Montana amid blowing and drifting snow. This image was taken during the afternoon of Saturday, Sept. 28, in Browning, Montana, and was one of the few images of the area that showed better visibility. (RWIS camera/Montana Department of Transportation)

1 p.m. MDT Saturday

By early afternoon local time, 13 inches of snow had been reported near Choteau, Montana. The report also mentioned that ice has started to cover highways that were previously plowed.

There has already been at least one vehicular accident amid slippery roads. Montana Highway Patrol trooper Amanda Villa posted on Twitter a car that had slipped into a ditch and flipped over. She reported that everyone who had been in the vehicle was okay.

11:30 a.m. MDT Saturday

A National Weather Service trained spotter reported that 3 inches of snow had fallen in Montana City, Montana, and that the trees are dropping significantly underneath the weight of the snow. As of 11:30 a.m. MDT, there are no reported downed trees or limbs observed in the area.

11 a.m. MDT Saturday

Rain transitioned to snow within the past hour at Spokane International Airpot in Washington. This is the first time it has snowed in September at the airport since 1926 when 1.4 inches snow fell, setting their all-time record amount of snowfall for the month.

By 10:45 a.m. MDT, 9 inches of snow had already fallen over Choteau, Montana.

10 a.m. MDT Saturday

The National Weather Service issued a high wind warning for Flathead Valley and Mission Valley, Montana, until Sunday at 9 a.m. MDT. By 10 a.m. MDT, the winds had already caused power outages affecting nearly 1,500 people near Flathead Lake, according to KPAX8.
